info.game_comments:
Maria Wenglinsky game 6.

(Jon: Talk about elbow room!  Only five people and some buffalo per square mile.  Clues on the wide-open spaces of Wyoming, next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: An ideal knight of this "Canterbury Tales" author was valorous but "prudent and as meek as a maid of his bearing"

(2, 1).clue: This boxer liked his nickname "Marvelous Marvin" so much that he had his name legally changed

(3, 1).clue: The first new variety of Eggo waffle Kellogg's made was one with this fruit in 1972

(4, 1).clue: Often employing animals, this type of short tale, like "The Fox and the Grapes", teaches moral lessons

(5, 1).clue: It opened its doors as an immigration station on January 1, 1892

(6, 1).clue: The title of an Irving Berlin song, it's how a famous pair danced in the film "Top Hat"

(1, 2).clue: Patches of plate armor were added to unprotected areas of this flexible garment of interlocked metal rings

(2, 2).clue: In a 27-year ring career, Archie Moore set a record by winning the most bouts, 141, in this way

(3, 2).clue: Poutine, a Montreal treat, is covered with gravy & this solid element of cheese

(4, 2).clue: Some novels have this added section about characters' later lives; the one in Ellison's "Invisible Man" is called this

(5, 2).clue: This missionary nurseryman did most of his work in Ohio & Indiana, where he died in 1845

(1, 3).clue: The name of this part of a knight's armor comes from an old French word meaning "glove"

(2, 3).clue: 3 Rays have won Olympic gold medals in boxing for the U.S.: Ray Mercer, Ray Seales & this "sweet" guy

(3, 3).clue: This Thai food flavoring comes from a tropical plant named for its citrusy smell

(4, 3).clue: This 3-letter term is inserted after a correctly quoted word or phrase that's misspelled or inaccurate

(5, 3).clue: Eli Bridge builds amusement rides like this one that's been making the rounds since 1893

(6, 3).clue: To give off a strong, unpleasant smell

(1, 4).clue: A dummy target called a quintain was used in practice tilts in preparation for this sport

(2, 4).clue: This bare-knuckles heavyweight champ was known as "The Great John L."

(3, 4).clue: Holishkes is one of the many names for leaves of this vegetable stuffed with meat

(4, 4).clue: From the French for "untying", it unties the plot after the climax of a novel

(5, 4).clue: In 1953 the Maryland Historical Society acquired an original 1814 manuscript of this for $26,400

(6, 4).clue: Onion relative that's a symbol of Wales

(1, 5).clue: In about 1119 in Jerusalem, knights Hugh de Payens & Godfrey of St. Omer founded this order of Christian knighthood

(2, 5).clue: 1 of 2 men to whom Floyd Patterson lost the World Heavyweight title

(3, 5).clue: Italian for "angry", it describes a pasta sauce spiced up with plenty of chiles

(4, 5).clue: This term for books printed before 1501 goes back to the Latin cunae, "a cradle"

(5, 5).clue: (Hi. I'm Larry King.)  This New York governor was the guest on the first "Larry King Live" on CNN June 1, 1985

(6, 5).clue: It's the word that means happening once a fortnight

(1, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew is outstanding in his field, complete with dilapidated barn and mountain range, in Grand Teton Nat'l Park, Wyoming.)  The Grand Tetons are an impressive part of the northern section of this much larger mountain chain

(2, 1).clue: "It's Too Late" & "So Far Away" were 1971 hits for her

(3, 1).clue: In 2003 she became the first New York senator ever appointed to the Senate Armed Services Committee

(4, 1).clue: When this letter is added to comic, it becomes a whole lot bigger

(5, 1).clue: Until Matsushita & Sony marketed these devices, people had to race home to catch "Police Woman"

(6, 1).clue: This leader's Cultural Revolution, 1966-1976, eliminated political rivals & threw Chinese cities into chaos

(1, 2).clue: The scandalous Teapot Dome is part of the area that got Casper into this business in the 1890s

(2, 2).clue: This group's "Louie Louie" made 1963 very interesting

(3, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Ari Fleischer.)  In 1999, after this woman left the Red Cross, I was communcations director for her presidential campaign

(4, 2).clue: Add this letter to moral & it becomes fatal

(5, 2).clue: A basic electronic calculator does multiplication by translating it into a series of this simpler operation

(6, 2).clue: His "New Diet Revolution" was on the mass-market paperback bestseller list over 2 years

(1, 3).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew writhes his palm in a lovely pink raft in the Snake River, Bridger-Teton Nat'l Forest, Wyoming.)  The Snake River may have gotten its name from a Shosone gesture, but it didn't mean "snake"; it meant the river was full of these

(2, 3).clue: "Stand By Me" hit the charts for him in 1961 & 1986

(3, 3).clue: She was serving as New Jersey's 50th governor when George W. Bush tapped her to head the EPA

(4, 3).clue: Adding this letter to heritage gives you a nice, secluded retreat

(5, 3).clue: In 2003 Billboard magazine started this new chart; the first No. 1, "Crazy In Love", had a total of 1,500

(6, 3).clue: From 1963 to 1978 this country had a "White Revolution": in 1979, partly as a backlash, it had an Islamic one

(1, 4).clue: (Kelly reports from horse country, horse in hand, in Grand Teton Nat'l Park, Wyoming.)  While living in Wyoming, Mary O'Hara created a classic equine literary character: "My Friend" this horse

(2, 4).clue: "The Thrill Is Gone"--at least it was for him in 1970

(3, 4).clue: She's the governor pictured here in 1994 with her then-opponent

(4, 4).clue: Add this letter to sale & it becomes a type of rock

(5, 4).clue: This machine for patients with faulty kidneys was developed during WWII; today some models fit under an airplane seat

(6, 4).clue: Economist Arnold Toynbee popularized this term to describe England's 18th & 19th c. economic development

(1, 5).clue: Wyoming's scenery has inspired many artists, so it's fitting that the state flower is the "Indian" this

(2, 5).clue: In 1979 this potent (potable) singer gave us "I Don't Know If It's Right"

(3, 5).clue: This playwright & Vanity Fair editor served in the House of Representatives from 1943 to 1947

(4, 5).clue: In a raid, add this letter & it may describe the fury & rage that you feel

(5, 5).clue: It's the basic geographic unit of wireless phone service

(6, 5).clue: Leaders of the 1989 Czech revolution, given this fabric-ated name, also led a '99 antigovernment protest

(0, 0).clue: "He is all pine and I am apple orchard.  My apple trees will never get across and eat the cones under his pines"
